text: I've never used an online training for Tableau, but FWIW, their tutorials/help sections are pretty solid, and if I didn't happen to find an example or answer there, I usually didn't have trouble finding good clear documentation from third party sites. Know it's not the exact answer you were looking for, but figured I'd add the context I could. Good luck! Tableau is amazing :slightly_smiling_face:

text: No - most of the time it's just a waste of space. better to use power words to boost CTR. unless you know your brand is likely to boost CTR

text: Hey pals! We're looking at our website top nav and trying to be a little more specific, both for SEO but also just for actual clarity. We're a small B2B IoT software and services company (basicallly: everything but hardware). Right now our top nav is Products & Services / Resources / Blog / About Us / Contact Us. I really want to change Products & Services to something more concrete, like Devices & Systems, but that's not exactly what we're selling. Software & Solutions is probably more on the money, but I feel like it's barely more interesting than Products & Services. Anyone have feelings to share?

elements.text: Hey pals! We're looking at our website top nav and trying to be a little more specific, both for SEO but also just for actual clarity. We're a small B2B IoT software and services company (basicallly: everything but hardware). Right now our top nav is Products & Services / Resources / Blog / About Us / Contact Us. I really want to change Products & Services to something more concrete, like Devices & Systems, but that's not exactly what we're selling. Software & Solutions is probably more on the money, but I feel like it's barely more interesting than Products & Services. Anyone have feelings to share?

text: Awesome! I've worked with <http://oden.io|oden.io> so I'll take a look.

so I'll take a look.

text: I see they go with Product and Solutions, separately

elements.text: I see they go with Product and Solutions, separately

text: Yeah, that was for both clarity and discoverability. People searching for a specific kind of solution will be different than somebody searching for a specific product they've already identified may solve their problem.

elements.text: Yeah, that was for both clarity and discoverability. People searching for a specific kind of solution will be different than somebody searching for a specific product they've already identified may solve their problem.

text: This is useful, thanks! Basically, I don't want to get in the way of people who want to buy software licenses (that's been the problem in the past) but we always want them to know that we can do more.

text:
Hey everyone!

We built a <https://soapboxhq.com/goal-examples|massive goals library> back in September and we’re still actively adding to it.

Question: We’re trying to add in goal examples for a CEO… But NO clue where to put it. If you were in my shoes… Where would you put it? :blush:

Where I’m struggling is… If we put leadership, do we remove the leadership roles from the specific departments (CMO, CTO, COO, etc) and put them in leadership because that feels less intuitive.

OR does the CEO just live as it’s own “department” which feels super empty.

Would love your thoughts!!

elements.text:
Hey everyone!

We built a
massive goals library

back in September and we’re still actively adding to it.

Question: We’re trying to add in goal examples for a CEO… But NO clue where to put it. If you were in my shoes… Where would you put it?

Where I’m struggling is… If we put leadership, do we remove the leadership roles from the specific departments (CMO, CTO, COO, etc) and put them in leadership because that feels less intuitive.

OR does the CEO just live as it’s own “department” which feels super empty.

Would love your thoughts!!

text: Does anyone have a good messaging framework that can be used for both brand and product messaing?

elements.text: Does anyone have a good messaging framework that can be used for both brand and product messaing?

text: I think it makes sense to have a Leadership department and stick all the C’s in there (I’d probably name it C-Suite but that’s personal preference). Particularly because a lot of C-level roles don’t fit neatly into departments (for example, Chief Operating Officer)

elements.text: I think it makes sense to have a Leadership department and stick all the C’s in there (I’d probably name it C-Suite but that’s personal preference). Particularly because a lot of C-level roles don’t fit neatly into departments (for example, Chief Operating Officer)

text: Thanks for the replies and the inspiration, everybody. I appreciate it.

elements.text: Thanks for the replies and the inspiration, everybody. I appreciate it.

text:
You know how people are cartoon-ifying themselves, putting themselves into various poses?

Is there a tool for doing the same but for an animal? In this case, I'm interested in making a cartoon character and using a tool to put it into various poses. Yes, this is for marketing.

text:
Hey everyone :wave::skin-tone-4:. I've some questions about CTAs in blogs.

1. Where do you think a CTA be placed in a blog post? 

2.What has worked for your blog? 

3. Should every blog post have a CTA? 


Okay that was more than one question. :sweat_smile: should have said quick questions.

elements.text: Hey everyone

. I've some questions about CTAs in blogs.

1. Where do you think a CTA be placed in a blog post? 

2.What has worked for your blog? 

3. Should every blog post have a CTA? 


Okay that was more than one question.
should have said quick questions.

text: I bet you get roughly 372829 different replies to this :innocent:

elements.text: I bet you get roughly 372829 different replies to this

text: I think if the CTA is contextually relevant to the rest of the post. I’m a big believer in putting CTAs all over the post :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: I think if the CTA is contextually relevant to the rest of the post. I’m a big believer in putting CTAs all over the post

text: Closing a post with a CTA is mandatory. Then it really depends... one thing I really like is doing conversion optimizations on pages with high traffic but low conversion (with for example CTAs like buttons, banners, text links)

elements.text: Closing a post with a CTA is mandatory. Then it really depends... one thing I really like is doing conversion optimizations on pages with high traffic but low conversion (with for example CTAs like buttons, banners, text links)

text: If you haven't read the CXL blog post on this topic, I highly recommend it. They have a couple others, but I'd start with this one: <https://cxl.com/blog/call-to-action/>

attachments.title: Mastering the Call to Action: Words, Color, Size, & Location | CXL
attachments.text: The right call to action can have a big impact on conversions. Find out how to choose the winning CTA font, text, size, and everything else!
